content.webTitle: Lacuna review – surprises amid Childhood's shoegaze

fields.headline: Lacuna review – surprises amid Childhood's shoegaze
fields.bodyText: London quartet Childhood were lumbered with Stone Roses comparisons after just one single, but they're more intriguing than that. There's enough in the circling guitar lines and dazed melodies of their debut album to induce reveries of late-80s British indie, but it's the ways they play against type that draw you in. Tides is a case in point: a sinuous soul track twitching against the drift of treated guitars. And whereas the blissed-out vocals of shoegaze tend to float along the path of least resistance, singer Ben Romans-Hopcraft springs surprises, delivering punchy choruses and twisting off in unexpected directions.
